David,
Well, iron vs. steel is a matter of the carbon content.  

http://ww=
w.thefabricator.com/Articles/Welding_Article.cfm?ID=3D685
http://www.roymec=
h.co.uk/Useful_Tables/Matter/Iron_Steel_Forms.html

In the Torigoye/Haynes =
"Tsuba an Aesthetic Study" there is a four step breakdown of hardness/carbo=
n content:

Goku Koko (very hard) C > 1.0%
Koko  (hard) 0.5% < C < 1.0%
Nan=
ko (soft) 0.25% < C < 0.5%
Goku Nanko (very soft) C < 0.25 %

Of course the=
 actual hardness depends on final heat treatment, so I'm not entirely sure =
how to take that.

I would be surprised if there isn't variation in the per=
centage carbon between guards, but I haven't seen any such metallurgical an=
alysis.  A correlation of measured hardness, carbon content and visual appe=
arance across a group of tsuba would be interesting.  I wouldn't be surpris=
ed if other factors (surface finish, applied patina, oxidation over time) c=
onfused any correlation of appearance with measured physical characteristic=
s.

Lacking data, here are some more anecdotes and random thoughts.

We hea=
r about modern swordsmiths sorting their tamahagane by carbon content based=
 on its color and texture, but this is before forging.  Appearance after fo=
rging is another matter.  

Yoshindo Yoshihara makes tosho and katchushi st=
yle tsuba after the old styles and bases his methods on observations from t=
he originals.  I talked to him about his methods a few years ago.  He said =
that he sometimes uses ordinary iron for his guards and sometimes tamahagan=
e.  If he uses tamahagane, he takes it from the low carbon portion of the b=
loom.  He said that he does not use steel.  He said that he could tell the =
difference in how the material (low C tamahagane vs. non-tatara iron)  work=
ed, but that there were no visible differences in the finished product.

He=
 does not do any sort of quench hardening.  "Just hammered iron.  Not very =
hard."  That doesn't mean that it was done that way in the past, but I have=
 checked this out with restorers of old guards and none of them had encount=
ered a guard hard enough to have been quench hardened.  This seems sensible=
 since a hardened guard would also be a brittle guard.  Of course if he's u=
sing iron, it cannot be quench hardened anyway.

Even high carbon tool stee=
l can be annealed to be quite soft.  If guards are forged to shape and left=
 to cool, it's not clear to me how much influence carbon content is going t=
o have on actual hardness.  I think that there's a bunch we don't know abou=
t the final heat treatment of historical guards, though.  How much does the=
 real hardness vary?  Some guards do look harder than others, is there a ph=
ysical difference?

Tekkotsu are described as regions of high carbon conten=
t.  That would imply steel or even beyond, at least in spots.  Guards with =
tekkotsu tend to be very slow to take on a natural patina when hanging outs=
ide when compared to softer (looking) guards that can recolor fairly quickl=
y.  Corrosion resistance can be affected by impurities.  Tekkotsu often loo=
k blacker and smoother than the surrounding metal.  I can believe that the =
percentage of carbon might have been varied for aesthetic reasons even if n=
ot for mechanical ones.  Using oroshigane the smith can vary the carbon con=
tent of his metal at will.

It's hard to say how many of the traditional ex=
planations are based on data.  Of course when it comes to kantei, you have =
to go on what you can sense, so it brings us back to these terms being qual=
itative rather than quantitative.

Jim

  I have heard, and read, a great deal of discussion a=
